title: Christopher Golden v Meta Platforms
headline: Christopher Golden v Meta Platforms
summary: Case reference Case C 3:23-cv-03417

title: Google’s wholesale copying of books to create an internet search tool was found to be fair use in Authors Guild v. Google
headline: Google’s wholesale copying of books to create an internet search tool was found to be fair use in Authors Guild v. Google – dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary: On Thursday 9 November 2023, US District Judge Vince Chhabria indicated that he would grant Meta's motion to dismiss the claims that content generated by Meta's LLaMA tool infringes their copyright (and also that LLaMA is itself an infringing work), but would give the plaintiffs permission to amend most of their claim.
takeaway: Complaints that don't connect copying to market harm risk dismissal. Tie training/outputs to measurable revenue impact on the catalog.

title: It is also worth noting that the Judge disagrees with the opinion expressed by Judge Alsup in the Bartz v Anthropic summary judgment decision
headline: It is also worth noting that the Judge disagrees with the opinion expressed by Judge Alsup in the Bartz v Anthropic summary judgment decision – rules AI training fair use.
summary: Given the finding on fair use, the Court has also dismissed the Plaintiffs' DMCA claim as Meta's removal of CMI could not have furthered an act of infringement. The Court must now consider how to deal with the remaining part of the infringement action relating to uploading of pirated copies of the Plaintiffs' copyrighted material via a peer-to-peer file sharing network.
takeaway: Even if training is ruled fair use, dataset acquisition can still create liability. For music publishers, scrutinize provenance of audio datasets and any scraping of pirated files.

title: Kadrey v Meta Platforms
headline: Kadrey v Meta Platforms
summary: Order consolidating cases against Meta 7 December 2023

title: This case has been consolidated with Kadrey v Meta
headline: This case has been consolidated with Kadrey v Meta
summary: The same set of authors, playwrights and screenwriters in proceedings against OpenAI have also brought a claim against Meta in the US District Court for the Northern District of California. This case focuses on Meta's LLaMa (Large Language Model Meta AI) and noted Meta's statements that LLaMa was trained using books including from the Books3 section of ThePile dataset (assembled from content available in 'shadow library' websites (including Bibliotik)), which the Plaintiffs contended includes their copyright works.

title: Judge Tigar in Doe I v GitHub
headline: Judge Tigar in Doe I v GitHub – dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary: The claims for unjust enrichment are dismissed but the Plaintiffs have been given leave to make one last attempt to state an unjust enrichment claim.
takeaway: Complaints that don't connect copying to market harm risk dismissal. Tie training/outputs to measurable revenue impact on the catalog.
